title: Angelina Jolie believes strong women are shaped by men in their lives
text:
Both Angelina and Elle Fanning believe female characters shouldn’t have to be tough (Picture: David M. Benett/Dave Benett/WireImage)

Angelina Jolie has opened up on the important role men can play in shaping young girls.

The Maleficent: Mistress Of Evil actress talked about how stories – whether it be in novels or movies – usually have female characters rely on men to become strong.

‘I think that, so often, when a story’s told which says “this is a strong woman”, she has to beat the man, or she has to be like the man, or she has to somehow not need the man,’ Angelina said last week at a press conference for the Disney film.

The 44-year-old believes young girls need to ‘find their own power’ without having to rely on men.

Referring to her own character Maleficent and Princess Aurora, who is portrayed by Elle Fanning, Angelina said: ‘We both very much need and love and learn from the men.

‘And so I think that’s also an important message for young girls, to find their own power, but to respect and learn from the men around them.’

Mistress of Evil is the sequel to 2014’s highly successful Maleficent and stars Ed Skrein, Chiwetel Ejiofor and Michelle Pfeiffer.

The actress plays a powerful fairy and protector of the moors (Picture: Disney Enterprises Inc)

‘We have strong women, but the character that is wrong in the film and has to be taken out is also a woman,’ the actress added. ‘We show very diverse types of women, between our characters, but also we have extraordinary men in the film, and I really want to press that point.’

At the same time, Elle agreed with Angelina and added that Princess Aurora’s strength isn’t in her physical form like in most children’s movies.

The 21-year-old said: ‘Aurora’s strength is her kindness, and she stays very true to herself, which is something I wanted to keep in the film.

‘She is soft and feminine and wants to be a wife and have babies, and that’s a beautiful, strong thing that isn’t portrayed a lot on screen.’

Fair point, Elle.

‘A lot of the princesses are like, “we’re gonna make her a strong princess! And make her tough, so we’re gonna make her fight!” And it’s like, is that what being a strong woman means?’ the Neon Demon actress added.

‘Like, we just have to have a sword and have armour on and go fight? Aurora can do that in a different way, in a pink dress, and it’s beautiful that she keeps her softness and vulnerabilities.’

Louder for the people in the back!
